awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Magneto Hydro Dynamic (MHD) Generation for Spacecraft Power
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide electric power generation for spacecraft that is environmentally clean, has much higher power generation density per volume and weight than any existing alternative, has high reliability and nearly no degradation over time.  This power generation will utilize a process called Magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) - a process that uses natural solar plasma produced by the Sun to provide electrical power. This technology will benefit society by allowing spacecraft and satellites to function more efficiently for longer periods of time. MHD generation also provides environmental benefits since it utilizes no hazardous materials and reduces the amount of fuel needed for launch, reducing carbon dioxide emissions. This project will also introduce a new type of ion funnel that is highly efficient and portable that can also be used in medical ion spectroscopy, resulting in reduced costs for this equipment and improved portability. The compact, high-density electromagnets developed can also be used to improve efficiency and power capability in many industrial and power system applications.  

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project addresses the problem of providing electrical power generation for spacecraft that can meet the demands for producing large amounts of electrical power while reducing payload launch mass requirements. The objectives of this research are to prove the feasibility of utilizing the solar wind plasma in space as well as to determine the performance of Magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) generation to produce electricity.  Modeling solar wind plasma conditions based on data from various space probes indicates that conditions of ion flux and plasma conductivity are conducive to support MHD power generation.  This research will answer the question of whether high-energy solar wind plasma can be harvested by MHD generation and unlock energy that is available. This research will involve design and development of a small MHD generator and testing a prototype in a vacuum plasma chamber that simulates solar wind plasma conditions.  The experimental results will be modeled with numerical simulations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Magnetohydrodynamic Electrical Power Generation for Spacecraft

 

 

This project investigated the feasibility and demonstration of generating electrical power for spacecraft operation by harnessing the energy and power produced by the sun in the form of the flowing naturally ionized solar space plasma. The process used is called Magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) generation which passes the ionized plasma flow through a magnetic field per the Faraday principle..  Unlike solar panels that utilize photons produced by the sun to produce electrical power, MHD instead draws an electrical current from the flow of charged particles (ions) to produce electrical power with the goal of producing larger quantities of power more efficiently and with increased reliability and with no functional degradation over time, unlike solar panels.

 

Summary of Research Outcomes

 

The outcomes of this research work are summarized as follows:

  • Twelve test prototype systems were designed, developed, and bench tested.
  • Three best performing test articles were tested at the Environmental Effects Laboratory at NASA Marshall Space Flight Center
  • Results of testing in simulated space plasma conditions proved that MHD generation is feasible and can generate electrical power using outer space ion plasma conditions.
  • Computer simulations of MHD generation were modeled to validate the system operation theory.
  • Power generation can be further improved by increasing the magnetic field strength, optimizing the MHD channel geometry, and matching the electrical load to the internal generator impedance.
  • A greater understanding of plasma characteristics and interaction as it pertains to MHD generator performance was obtained and enabled an evaluation of MHD generator performance based on the laboratory testing and provide extrapolation to actual outer space solar plasma conditions.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

This research is aimed at meeting the needs of advancing the technology for space-based  electrical power generation with new knowledge and deeper understandings of astrophysics and new  techniques to capture and utilize space plasma in the inter-solar system space environment.  The knowledge gained from this research will increase the public scientific literacy on the subject of plasma physics, MHD generation, and ion particle control.  This research may also stimulate broader partnerships between academia and industry in the field of space power and space plasma physics.

 

Broader Impacts

 

This project will generate economic value for customers and investors while reducing harm to natural resources that are typically created in the production of high-power solar panels required for spacecraft.  MHD generation requires no rare earth metals and produces no toxic waste during manufacturing and will reduce the reliance on foreign-sourced rare earth elements thus mitigating associated environmental damage, and ultimately produces long-term sustainability in product value for the benefit of the environment and communities worldwide.

 

The development of the electromagnets that will be used for this project could provide new designs for use in medical applications such as magnetic resonant imaging (MRI) for more compact, portable MRI units for use in remote areas. 

 

The design and testing of the electrodynamic ion scoop that was developed and tested in this project  may benefit the medical area since ion funnels are used in mass spectrometry.  The medical ion funnels currently used are heavy and have limited portability, and only a few are in existence.  The ion funnel design used in this project is light weight and portable.  Ion funnels are useful in various medical research applications and offer potential superior benefits to traditional ways of collecting and focusing ion streams.  It may be possible from the research proposed in developing a lightweight ion scoop for this space-based project that larger, more portable, and more efficient ion funnels could be developed for spectrometry and other medical applications.

Also, higher power electromagnets will find useful applications in manufacturing, such as automobile factories where steel sheets are lifted in place using electromagnets and in assembly lines utilizing robotic machines.

 

Further, a potential societal benefit of the proposed research for a MHD generator could include developing a new source of efficient energy power on earth. Knowledge gained from this research may open the door to possible terrestrial applications of MHD generation to provide a more efficient, sustainable source of clean energy for our society.

 

 

Six Figures are included herewith that show the test articles and graphical results of the voltages and power produced.
